title: Refactor OpenPlanner code following ROS C++ code style

comments.comment_text:
@hatem-darweesh this looks great, thanks for taking the time to flesh out the code. Did you use `clang-format`? Dave Coleman put up this `clang-format` configuration file that matches the ROS1 C++ code style:

https://github.com/davetcoleman/roscpp_code_format

In addition to that, ROS2 also has a configuration file for `uncrustify` with the ROS2 code style (the ROS1 code style guide will eventually converge with ROS2's):

https://github.com/ament/ament_lint/blob/master/ament_uncrustify/ament_uncrustify/configuration/ament_code_style.cfg

I'm working on integrating ROS2's build system (ament) with Autoware, which will bring automatic code style checking (in addition to other stuff), you can have a look at it at:

https://github.com/esteve/Autoware/tree/feature/use_ament_vector_map

ament supersedes catkin and does not require ROS2, so we can use it with Autoware and ROS1.

Adding automatic code checking and generating a test report is as simple as adding these two lines:

https://github.com/esteve/Autoware/commit/849e1261cd4678de5407085d68cc2b380103e04b#diff-d47e2c80dcb7a36bc8d73ffcb44993bdR57

@esteve Thank you for the information. 
yes, I used clang format. as explained in #1771 

That would be great for new code , what about the existing one? should I stop refactoring OpenPlanner? 
I am looking forward to use ROS2 with Autoware. 

do you recommend to use ROS2 code style from now ? 
what is the difference between using "ament" and "colcon" as build tools ?

> That would be great for new code , what about the existing one?

Eventually all existing code will be ported to ament, so that the migration to ROS2 is easier.

> should I stop refactoring OpenPlanner?

Feel free to keep making changes to OpenPlanner, of course :-) But now that colcon will be part of Autoware 1.10 and ament will be in 1.11, we have the opportunity to add the ament linters to existing packages. However, this shouldn't block you from refactoring OpenPlanner, we can always port it to ament after or during 1.11.

> I am looking forward to use ROS2 with Autoware.

So am I! :-)

> do you recommend to use ROS2 code style from now ?

Both styles are very very very similar, my recommendation is that you continue with the changes you're making and we merge them, and once we have the ament infrastructure in Autoware, we can port OpenPlanner to ament and check if your changes pass the ROS2 checks.

> what is the difference between using "ament" and "colcon" as build tools ?

Basically, a build system comprises the functions and macros that are added to a build definition to find a package's dependencies (e.g. the build_depend tags in package.xml help rosdep install the dependencies), how to generate messages, etc.

A build tool is the program that knows how to read the metadata (package.xml) and the build definition (CMakeLists.txt) to produce a library or an executable.

Back in ROS1, the build system and the build tool were the same: catkin. catkin_make could only build catkin packages. In ROS2, we introduced ament, the evolution of the catkin build system, and had to create ament_tools to support the ament build system.

But that was just too messy, because now you needed a different tool for a different build system, and to solve that, colcon was created. colcon understands packages that are written for the catkin (ROS1), ament (ROS2), CMake, setuptools (Python), Gradle (Java), etc. build systems, so we can now use the same tool for building workspaces that contain packages for different build systems.

This is a huge benefit for us, because we can have code written for ROS1 that use the catkin build system, but also ROS1 packages with the ROS2 build system (ament), and packages entirely written for ROS2 all in the same workspace. So instead of rewriting Autoware entirely for ROS2, we can do it step by step: first convert the build system of some of the packages to ament, add the ros1_bridge, add new packages that use ROS2, etc.

The link I pasted before is just an example of a ROS1 package, ported to ament and showing how the ament linters help keeping the code clean.
@esteve Thanks a lot of explaining in detail, now I fully understand.

@gbiggs, Your request for switching to Apache 2.0 has been addressed. Regarding why this file (access_private.h) is required, it's because presently, ROS bag API protects bag file's index entry, which is required to read it in random fashion.
I looked at what you are doing and at the rosbag API. I think that because `rosbag::View` is a friend of `MessageInstance` you would be better off making a custom view to provide random access.

There two reasons that merely instancing the rosbag View class is not enough for random access bag:
1) There is a built-in iterator inside View class, but it is designed for sequential access
2) It is true that MessageInstance is friend of View, but not derivatives of View. Therefore I cannot access the index entries of all message instances directly, except it is made public (only possible when changing ROSbag API).

You would not necessarily have to follow the API of the `view` class since it's for an internal tool use.
However, you are right about not getting the friend privelages.

Using the approach of breaking the rosbag API is nasty and introduces maintainability issues. Here's what I think you should do:

- Since this is not going into 1.11, you need to make a fork and do a new PR from there anyway.
- In your fork, make one branch for each tool you are proposing so we can deal with each one individually.
- For the tool using rosbag, make the necessary changes in the rosbag API so you don't need to circumvent it. Propose them in a PR to the rosbag repository.
- Submit your tool as-is, but also submit a feature request to change it to use the changed rosbag API once that gets released in a ROS version we support (it is possible it would get released in Melodic if it doesn't change how the API is used for any other code).

We can accept the PR for that tool conditional on there being a proposal to change the rosbag API and your tool intending to use it in the future.
This needs to be merged to develop before the Autoware 1.10 cutoff so the links on the GtiHub repo point to the correct GitLab pipelines.

@sgermanserrano @aohsato I've created a pull request https://github.com/sgermanserrano/Autoware/pull/1 into this pull request. Would you comment my pull request? I can modify or revert any of the changes in my pull request :)

## Description
- The first arg indigo|kinetic is removed for the inconsistency @aohsato mentioned, i.e., `./run.sh indigo -t 1.7.0-kinetic`
- Set default tag latest-kinetic
- Output image name and shared dir info even if tag and repo are not specified
- Add -h option for help

## Usage
- Option `-h` outputs `Usage: $0 [-t <tag>] [-r <repo>] [-s <Shared directory>]`
- Option `-t` specifies tag (Default: `latest-kinetic`)
- Option `-r` specifies repo (Default: `autoware/autoware`)
- Option `-s` specifies shared dir (Default: `/home/$USER/shared_dir`)
- `./run.sh` outputs `Using autoware/autoware:latest-kinetic` and `Shared directory: /home/$USER/shared_dir` even if tag and repo are not specified

I've discussed with @shinpei0208 and @gbiggs how we should go. Since all the activities in TierIV depend on this branch, we'd like to minimize the gap between what TierIV is doing and what the community can do.

@kfunaoka and @esteve - reproducing this message here from astuff/automotive_autonomy_msgs#7 for visibility:

Please be aware: This repository (previously platform_automation_msgs) and the packages under it are changing names. This was necessary to make the package names less generic and was required by the OSRF guys before the packages could be released into the build farm. These changes are covered in astuff/automotive_autonomy_msgs#8.

Looking at Autoware, the package module_comm_msgs was the only package used by that project which contained messages in this repo. The two messages that were used - SteerMode and SpeedMode - will now live under automotive_platform_msgs and this will need to be changed in Autoware to use the apt installs.

Note: This should not cause any changes with the current version of Autoware because the submodule is tied to a specific commit and a clone request for the previous repo name will redirect.

@esteve radar_msgs does not seems to be used in Autoware. Is it beneficial to add radar_msgs as submodule? Or another reason?

@kfunaoka that's true, `radar_msgs` is not being used in Autoware, but it was spun off from `platform_automation_msgs`, so using the latter's `master` branch now requires `astuff_sensor_msgs` to be in the workspace. We can avoid adding a new submodule for `astuff_sensor_msgs` by pinning the `platform_automation_msgs` submodule to the latest tagged release (1.7) which still shipped with `radar_msgs`. I've submitted https://github.com/CPFL/Autoware/pull/1420 instead, which just uses a tagged release for `platform_automation_msgs`

@esteve I understand. Autoware requires `platform_automation_msgs`, and `platform_automation_msgs` requires `astuff_sensor_msgs`. So #1417 or #1420 is required. It is difficult to select which one is better. For now, `platform_automation_msgs` v1.7 is good for us. #1420 is selected tentatively.
I'm closing this in favor of #1420 However, in the long term, it'd be better if the message packages are released into the ROS index (https://github.com/astuff/platform_automation_msgs/issues/7)
This is still a work in progress. I simply rebased autowarefoundation/autoware#1167 and pushed it here.
I can confirm this solves the OpenGL issues with opening rviz
@esteve Is this PR still valid?

> @esteve Is this PR still valid?

Same question here.
@esteve _ping_

@gbiggs / @MTDzi - Based on https://github.com/autowarefoundation/autoware/blob/e7c12b0d1fd93f157888b22e82964f93eaf056d4/docker/generic/run.sh#L123 it looks like at least `master` supports the --runtime=nvidia option which is only available with nvidia_docker2 (nvidia_docker used the actual `nvidia-docker` command instead). I just tested it with `bash autoware/docker/generic/run.sh` and it appears to work correctly on my 18.04 host. The results from `nvidia-smi` look correct.

[1] https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/common-build-problems/#My-build-fails-unexpectedly

@esteve Can we solve the problem by both travis_wait for no output and travis_retry for network error?
https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/common-build-problems/#build-times-out-because-no-output-was-received

@bdholt1 unfortunately the problem with https://travis-ci.org/CPFL/Autoware/jobs/408495848 is that the worker didn't even start, so none of the code in `.travis.yml` is even run, there's nothing we can do, except restart the build.

@kfunaoka unfortunately `travis_wait` only helps if the code in `.travis.yml` is actually run, but in many cases Travis doesn't start a worker and the build time outs, causing it to fail. The only thing that can be done in that case is to just trigger a new build.

### My memo
tf::TransformBroadcaster starts subscribing topics when it is initialized.
If tf::TransformBroadcaster is a local variable (not static or not global), 
it can not send transform that is published outside the variable scope.

@dejanpan 

> @esteve were you able to test this on any of arm machines (e.g. drivePX2?).

Yes, though there's a couple fixups that need to be applied after compiling Autoware so that the paths make sense when running on the DrivePX. Unfortunately ROS workspaces are not easily relocatable, but a bit of `sed` fixes that:

`find devel/ -type f -exec grep -Iq . {} \; -and -exec sed -i -e 's#/sysroot/aarch64##g' {} \;`

The following line is needed if the Autoware workspace is exported to the Docker container as a volume with a different path other than the one in the DrivePX (e.g. `/home/nvidia/Autoware`):

`find devel/ -type f -exec grep -Iq . {} \; -and -exec sed -i -e 's#PATH_ON_THE_HOST#/home/nvidia/Autoware#g' {} \;`

> @esteve just one Q - what would need to happen for this PR to also work the nvidia docker as e.g. in here: #1167?

I'm working on that, but I wanted to get this first up for review. Here's what I'm doing now:

- add the `x86_64` CUDA APT repository to the `sysroot` stage Docker
- install the `cuda-*-cross-aarch64*` packages. Even if these packages are in the `x86_64` repository, they're actually targeting `arm64`. There are some packages (e.g. `cuda-license*`) that target the incorrect architecture (`all` instead of `x86_64`)
- copy the libraries and configuration files from the `sysroot` intermediate stage to `/sysroot/aarch64` in the builder stage.

I'm also trying to figure out how to this all without all the `sed` stuff, but I've given that a lower priority, as I wanted to have something working now that could be iterated from.

@Mani-Sadhasivam , @yk-fujii 
Thanks for your great works.
I'm one of the developer who contributed to implement `dpm_ttic`.

Regarding to
> `1. FLOAT = abs(FLOAT) doesn't really makes sense. Hence remove that.`

As the `thresh` is signed value, I think removing `abs` can leads to collapsing.
I suggest using `std::abs` because it has template declaration.
(Actually, `FLOAT` can be `float` or `double`. It is switched inside `Autoware/ros/src/computing/perception/detection/lib/image/dpm_ttic/cpu/switch_float.h` )

Best.

In `nodes/ndt_matching_monitor/README.md`
* "Subscribed topics" and "Published topics" titles are incorrect, swap them.

In `nodes/ndt_matching_monitor/ndt_matching_monitor.cpp`
* Perhaps rename `score_threshold_delta` to `score_delta_threshold`. 
* The default value of `score_threshold_delta` (14) is huge even more for a difference (delta), how did you come to that value? From experiments I found a score of under 2 is reasonable, for delta should be even lower.
* In my implementation I kept the average of score values but you are using the score differences `score_delta_`. The instantaneous score difference is prone to simple errors, whereas keeping the average of "delta" values (say, over 1 second) is simple to implement and more robust. 
* The combination of  `score_delta_`  and `iteration_count_` as
```c++
if (iteration_count_ < iteration_threshold_warning_ 
    && score_delta_ < score_threshold_delta_)
```

does not warrant accurate NDT error detection. I'm sending several evaluation data over co-sense4 channel for you to see.  
* The `ndt_matching_monitor` should know when to give up: no matter how many times you initialize pose (BTW, `/initialpose` is 2D) NDT won't converge (GNSS denied environment, multipath errors, etc.) `ndt_matching_monitor` should issue some topic telling the vehicle to initiate stop maneuver or the like. @bdholt1, I agree on both that you should ditch nvidia-docker v1 and that it would be better to exclude source code from the docker image. That is how we use docker at our company too.

The docker image should provide you with a development environment in which you can compile the autoware code (i.e. with all compile-time dependencies available). You can also make a runtime image which contains all the compiled software, but I would advice you to look into catkin install targets to make the deployed filesystem cleaner. When using the install targets you specify a file structure which contains only the files that need to be deployed (e.g. the binaries, launch files, param files, but not the src/header files). Just take a look at any official ros package github repo (e.g. https://github.com/ros-planning/navigation) for an example.

Some recommendations:
- figure out catkin install targets, to more cleanly deploy the code.
- consider switching to catkin_tools, rather than catkin_make. In my opinion, it is faster (especially for large catkin workspaces), cleaner, and more user friendly. It is created and maintained by the people behind ROS, but for some odd reason, it was never pushed as the official recommended successor of catkin_make (probably to avoid the migration troubles/frustrations that it would enforce to all ROS users). When switching you probably run into some cmake issues (as catkin_tools has no "cmake crosstalk" and thus is a bit more strict on your catkin correctness, i.e. the CMakeLists.xtx and package.xml). With catkin tools, just run `catkin config --install` (somewhat similar to `catkin_make install`) to enable the install space. Note that in ROS2, install targets will become obligatory (the devel workspace disappears in favor of the install workspace)..
- make two images (check e.g. apollo images too https://hub.docker.com/r/apolloauto/apollo/tags/): 
  - `autoware-dev-<version>` -> no code, no actual autoware
  - `autoware-release-<version>` -> containing deployed autoware code (no code, only binaries and "share" files like params / launch)
- for each, you need to make an nvidia and a non nvidia version (the patch I provided will make opengl apps such as rviz work for nvidia, but then its broken on intel integrated graphics...). e.g.
  - `autoware-dev-<version>-nvidia` and `autoware-dev-<version>`

We have a check_nvidia bash function that automatically can 'patch' a docker run command to take care, see this example:

```bash
check_nvidia(){
  if nvidia-smi &> /dev/null; then
    export NV_RUN="--runtime=nvidia"
    export NV_TAG_SUFFIX="-nvidia"
  else
    export NV_RUN=""
    export NV_TAG_SUFFIX=""
  fi
}

# adds GUI support and few other tricks
export DOCKER_COMMON_ARGS="--env=DISPLAY \
                           --env=XDG_RUNTIME_DIR \
                           --env=QT_X11_NO_MITSHM=1 \
                           --device=/dev/dri:/dev/dri \
                           -v /tmp/.X11-unix:/tmp/.X11-unix:rw \
                           -v /etc/localtime:/etc/localtime:ro"

xhost +local:docker
check_nvidia
docker run ${NV_RUN} ${DOCKER_COMMON_ARGS:?} -it --rm \
   --name="autoware" \
   -v /dev/bus/usb:/dev/bus/usb \
   -v /home/$USER/.Xauthority:/home/autoware/.Xauthority \
   -v "$HOME/docker_shared:/home/autoware/docker_shared" \
   -v autoware_home:/home/autoware \
   -v /media:/media \
   --net=host  \
   --add-host autoware:127.0.0.1 \
   --hostname=autoware \
   --privileged \
   autoware/autoware:1.7.0-kinetic${NV_TAG_SUFFIX}
```

Feel free to do with this advice whatever you like. I suggest you take it over from here from me and make some issues (stories) out of it if you like.

hi, I summarized some points of self-driving car software architecture from your autoware package.

will you need this kind of overview or put it into github? if you need, pls tell me, and I will send to you.

following is one of snapshot:

![knowledge](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8703449/35722307-bd29f09c-0830-11e8-89c3-4728985888a0.PNG)

## Added latch support and threshold score

This can be set from the command line in the parameters section as:
`rosrun road_wizard region_tlr_mxnet _image_raw_topic:=/camera0/image_source _network_definition_file:=/PATH/TO/FILE/network_definition.json _pretrained_model_file:=/PATH/TO/FILE/pretrained_weights.params _use_gpu:=true _score_threshold:=0.95 _change_state_threshold:=5`

Being `score_threshold` default **0.9** and `change_state_threshold` is **2**.

`score_threshold` defines the minimum score to be accepted by the classifier. In the example above the classifier should report at least **0.95**, otherwise, the state returned by the node will be UNDEFINED. 

`change_state_threshold` defines the number of times the classifier should report the **same result** to be accepted as valid. Otherwise, the previous state will be reported, until a valid new result is got.
